bibl.title: Letter from Walter Reed to Jefferson Randolph Kean, September 24, 1901

div1.p: Reed expresses great appreciation for Kean's recommendation that he apply himself to become Surgeon General, but says he will not join the ranks of those who “beg” for promotion. He informs Kean of Lawrence Reed's upcoming wedding, then recommends that Camp Lazear be discontinued. [Courtesy of The Albert and Shirley Small Special Collections Library, University of Virginia Library]

div1.head: Letter from Walter Reed to Jefferson Randolph Kean, September 24, 1901
div1.opener:
Private
WAR DEPARTMENT,
SURGEON GENERAL'S OFFICE,
ARMY MEDICAL MUSEUM AND LIBRARY,
WASHINGTON.
Sept. 24,
1901
My dear Major Kean:
div1.p:
That
I have woefully neglected
you goes without saying, and
it is needless for me to add
that I am heartily ashamed
of myself. But really, my
dear Commandante, when yours
of Sept. 1st came, I was so
“balled up” with the work
of the board and in trying, at
the same time, to make ready
a paper on “The prevention
of yellow fever” which Car-
rol & I wanted to present
at Buffalo on Septr 16th, that,
be it to my very great dis-
credit recorded, I put aside
your letter, after enjoying its
contents very much, and thus
neglected the pleasures and
fruits of friendship for the
every day, dry and dustying
things of this wretched, hust-
ling world. For all of this
I now ask your knightly
pardon. And now as if to
emphasize my neglect and for-
getfulness, here comes your
other letter of Sept. 16th, which
touches me very, very deeply,
Commandante mio Carrissimo.
How shall I reply to it?
I have even slept on it
over night and yet I don't
know what to say. To know that
I have your friendship and
good wishes in such a matter
is a real and unfeigned delight.
I cannot thank you and other
friends sufficiently for the kind
words that have been written
and spoken. These repay me
a thousand times for anything
that I may have done to help
along the fight against the
common enemy - “pallida mors”.
But, my commandante mio,
when you and others ask me
to enter into a bitter struggle
for the Surgeon Generalcy, you
ask me to do what my better
sense tells me to avoid.
Please understand that I
have no false modesty about
this matter, or lack of
ambition to reach the highest
position in the Medical Dept.
Like my good friend, Major
Hoff, I believe that every one
of us should take such inter-
est in the welfare and good
name of his Department as to
wish to became its head sooner
or later; & so if I said that I
had no such ambition, I
would not be speaking
candidly. Then, again, I be-
lieve that the work accom-
plished in Cuba, which means
more to for the health and commer-
cial interests of our country
than we can now estimate, deserves some reward.
I believe that I speak nothing
but the truth, when I say that
if the man who captured Agui-
naldo deserved a Brigadier -
Generalcy in the line, the
WAR DEPARTMENT,
SURGEON GENERAL'S OFFICE,
ARMY MEDICAL MUSEUM AND LIBRARY,
WASHINGTON.
2) man who captured “yellow
Jack” deserves a similar
promotion, at least, in the
staff! But I only say this
to you as one of my best
friends. It does not mean
that I should enter the strug-
gle with Brown, Smart,
Dewitt, O'Reilly, Pope, Hoff,
etal. Indeed to do so, would
be utterly repulsive to my
better feelings, for I am
so old fashioned as to be-
lieve that the office should
seek the man and not the
man be compelled to beg
for the office. So, my dear
Commandante, if General Wood
who is so well able to judge,
has spoken in a most com-
plimentary way of the value of
the work done in Cuba, I
feel profoundly grateful
to him; but for this very
reason, I could never go
to him and ask him to rec-
ommend me for promotion.
If it came from him unsolic-
ited, then I, like any other man,
would feel very much flat-
tered, but I would rather
die a thousand deaths than
to be put in the attitude
of a beggar! Please don't
misunderstand me. You must
know that I regard Gen. Wood
as representing the very highest
type of the American citizen
and that I have valued & still
value his friendship very
highly, and am proud to reckon
myselfhim amongst my friends. On more
than one occasion I have had
reason to believe that he regards
me highly as a friend and a
medical officer of the Army.
Two years ago, I begged him
to become a candidate for
the Surgeon Generalcy, as I
considered him as the one man
who could do most for our Corps;
but it doesn't follow that he
has an equally good opinion
of me. If he has, then I am
sure that, at the proper time,
he will doso express him-
self, without any suggestion
of mine. If he does not, then
it would show that he prefers
some one else. I agree with
that his influence will be very
great with the administration.
Indeed, I do not doubt that he
will select the next Surgeon
General, and for my part, just
so he doesn't select Dr. Pope, I
am certain that I shall not
be disturbed in the least.

Please give much love to your
dear wife. I cannot believe
that she is a day over eighteen!
What a happy man you should
be to possess such an angelic.
creature. Kiss the dear babies.
You will soon receive Lawrence's Wed-
ding Cards, as he will be married
at Fort Reno, Okla, on Oct. 28. Mar-
ries a Georgetown girl. Miss Black-
ford. He is now on temporary duty at
Fort Logan H. Root, Little Rock, Ark.
I saw dear old Gorgas at Buffalo, and
went on a toot with him. I see no
reason for holding on longer to Camp
Lazear. Send Carroll home.
